key_insight: RadarGen is a camera-conditioned diffusion model that synthesizes realistic automotive radar point clouds by generating bird's‑eye‑view (BEV) radar maps (including RCS and Doppler) and converting them back to point clouds, enabling radar-like data from only multi-view cameras.
problem_solved: Addresses the scarcity and cost of labeled radar point‑cloud data for autonomous driving by providing a way to generate realistic radar measurements from readily available camera imagery.
method: Adapt image‑latent diffusion to the radar domain: generate BEV radar maps that encode spatial layout plus radar cross section (RCS) and Doppler attributes conditioned on multi‑view camera features.
Lightweight recovery module: convert generated BEV maps into discrete radar point clouds (locations, RCS, Doppler) for downstream use.
Cross‑modal alignment: fuse multi‑view visual features with diffusion sampling (e.g., cross‑attention or image guidance) to ensure generated radar is consistent with the visual scene.
impact: Enables large‑scale synthetic radar data for training and evaluating perception and sensor‑fusion models, reducing dependence on costly radar annotation and improving robustness of autonomous systems in varied scenarios.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: multi‑view cameras -> BEV visual feature fusion -> diffusion generator -> BEV radar maps -> point‑cloud reconstruction.
Side‑by‑side comparison: ground‑truth radar point cloud vs. RadarGen output (overlayed on RGB/BEV).
Attribute heatmaps: separate visualizations for RCS and Doppler to show attribute fidelity.
Quantitative charts: FID/metric improvements and downstream task gains (e.g., detection/segmentation with synthetic radar augmentation).
paper_title: RadarGen: Automotive Radar Point Cloud Generation from Cameras
paper_authors: Tomer Borreda, Fangqiang Ding, Sanja Fidler, Shengyu Huang, Or Litany
